fr:title.text: Additive functors are those that commute with direct sums

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Additive functors are those that commute with direct sums

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A functor A\xrightarrow {F} B of additive categories is additive if and only if it preserves direct sums.

fr:p.fr:link: Hom-set addition can equivalently be defined by taking direct sums.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Categories and sheaves
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @book{riehl-2017, title = {Categories and Sheaves}, author = {Kashiwara, Masaki and Schapira, Pierre}, isbn = {978-3-540-27950-1}, publisher = {Springer Berlin}, year = {2005}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Categories and sheaves, which emerged in the middle of the last century as an enrichment for the concepts of sets and functions, appear almost everywhere in mathematics nowadays.

This book covers categories, homological algebra and sheaves in a systematic and exhaustive manner starting from scratch, and continues with full proofs to an exposition of the most recent results in the literature, and sometimes beyond.

The authors present the general theory of categories and functors, emphasising inductive and projective limits, tensor categories, representable functors, ind-objects and localization. Then they study homological algebra including additive, abelian, triangulated categories and also unbounded derived categories using transfinite induction and accessible objects. Finally, sheaf theory as well as twisted sheaves and stacks appear in the framework of Grothendieck topologies.
An additive category is a preadditive category with finite direct sums. (In particular, it has nullary direct sums, hence a zero object.)
An additive functor is an enriched functor between preadditive categories. Explicitly, this means it is a functor which acts on hom-sets by homomorphisms.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D preserves limits if for every diagram J\xrightarrow {K} C and every limit cone over K, the image of this cone under F is a limit cone over FK.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D between categories C and D consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, an object Fx\in D;
for each morphism f\in C(x, y), a morphism Ff\in D(Fx, Fy).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must preserve the structure of the category, namely identities and composites, meaning:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, F1_x = 1_{Fx};
for each pair x\xrightarrow {f}y\xrightarrow {g}z in C, F(gf) = (Fg)(Fg).
